ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed a much stronger sense of the forms and strategies contained within the autobiography genre.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The best part of the class is you can apply the strategies you learn to your own writing and see it improved because of that. The weakness is that the grad school students either haven't done the reading or choose not to speak, since participation is not part of the grade, and so that means sometimes a few undergrads carry the class, along with Professor Stepto, who has a propensity to speak for a while.

The syllabus in this class was very well considered. I liked that the books were organized by theme rather than just chronologically, and I liked that Professor Stepto came in with a plan of the major themes of each book. Sometimes I felt like class discussions were not great, since people did not necessarily participate in the discussions unless explicitly asked by the professor.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: You might think you can only write one autobiography. But there are many ways if you take this class.

Take this course just so you can get to know Professor Stepto he is incredibly kind and knowledgable, and clearly cares so much about teaching. The books are all interesting and the class is extremely low-stress with a high payoff.
